lessons.title: Lesson 0.1: What is a Computer Program?

contentSections.title: The Problem
contentSections.content:
Imagine you're trying to teach your younger sibling how to make a peanut butter and jelly sandwich. You leave the kitchen for 5 minutes and return to find:

‚Ä¢ The peanut butter jar is unopened
‚Ä¢ They spread jelly on the outside of the bread
‚Ä¢ The knife is on the floor
‚Ä¢ They're confused why it didn't work

What went wrong? You assumed they knew things: "spread" means using a knife, "on the bread" means the inside face, you need to open jars first. But your sibling followed your words EXACTLY as you said them‚Äîno more, no less.

THIS IS HOW COMPUTERS WORK.

A computer is the most obedient, most literal "sibling" imaginable. It will do exactly what you tell it‚Äînothing more, nothing less. It has zero common sense. It can't guess what you meant. It can't improvise.

contentSections.title: Programming is Recipe Writing (But More Precise)
contentSections.content:
Let's compare a recipe for humans vs. a recipe for a computer:

Recipe for a Human:
1. Preheat oven to 350¬∞F
2. Mix the ingredients
3. Bake for 20 minutes

Why this works: Humans know what "mix" means. They know ovens have dials.

Recipe for a Computer:
1. LOCATE the oven dial
2. TURN the dial clockwise until display shows 350
3. WAIT until the light labeled "READY" turns green
4. OPEN the ingredient_box
5. FOR EACH item in ingredient_box:
   a. MEASURE the item using measuring_cup
   b. POUR into bowl labeled "mixing_bowl"
6. PICK UP the spoon labeled "mixing_spoon"
7. MOVE spoon in circular motion for 60 seconds
8. PLACE mixing_bowl into oven
9. START timer for 20 minutes
10. WAIT until timer beeps

Notice: Every action is explicit. Every object is identified. No assumptions are made.

This is programming. You're writing a recipe so detailed that something with ZERO intelligence can follow it perfectly.

contentSections.title: What is a Computer Program, Really?
contentSections.content:
A computer program is:

1. A SEQUENCE OF INSTRUCTIONS (step 1, step 2, step 3...)
2. WRITTEN IN A LANGUAGE THE COMPUTER UNDERSTANDS (like Java, Python, C++)
3. THAT MANIPULATES DATA (numbers, text, images)
4. TO PRODUCE A RESULT (a calculation, a webpage, a video game)

Breaking it down:

Instructions: Computers execute instructions one at a time, in order. Examples:
‚Ä¢ "Store the number 5 in a box"
‚Ä¢ "Add 3 to whatever is in the box"
‚Ä¢ "Show the result on the screen"

Language: Computers don't understand English. They understand machine code (0s and 1s). But writing in 0s and 1s is torture, so we use programming languages like Java, which look more like English. Java gets translated into machine code automatically.

Data: Programs work with information: numbers, text, images, videos, sounds.

Results: Every program has a purpose‚Äîcalculating, displaying, storing, or transforming data.

contentSections.title: Key Insight: Computers Are Dumb (And That's Okay)
contentSections.content:
Computers CANNOT:
‚úó Guess what you meant
‚úó Improvise or adapt
‚úó Understand context
‚úó Learn without being programmed to learn

But computers CAN:
‚úì Follow instructions perfectly, billions of times per second
‚úì Remember massive amounts of data flawlessly
‚úì Repeat tasks without getting tired or bored
‚úì Do exactly what you tell them, every single time

Your job as a programmer: Be the smart one. Give the instructions. The computer will be the obedient one.

lessons.title: Lesson 0.2: Your First Java Program

contentSections.title: The Problem: Talking to the Computer
contentSections.content:
You now understand that programming is writing detailed instructions. But there's a catch: you can't just write instructions in English. You need to use a programming language.

Why? Because English is ambiguous. "Turn left" could mean many things. But in a programming language, every symbol, every word, has ONE exact meaning.

Java is one of the most popular programming languages in the world. It's used by millions of developers to build everything from Android apps to banking systems to video games.

Today, you'll write your first Java program. It won't do much‚Äîit'll just display a message on the screen. But you'll understand every single character of code.

contentSections.title: Java Code is Like a Formal Letter
contentSections.content:
Imagine you're writing a letter to a government official. You can't just scribble:
"Hey! Need help. Thanks!"

You need proper structure:

Dear Official,
I am writing to request...
Sincerely,
Your Name

Java is the same. It has a formal structure. Every program needs certain pieces in certain places. Once you learn the structure, you can focus on the logic.

contentSections.title: Anatomy of a Java Program
contentSections.content:
Here's the simplest possible Java program:

public class HelloWorld {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        System.out.println("Hello, World!");
    }
}

Let's break it down, line by line:

1. 'public class HelloWorld {'
   - 'public' means anyone can use this
   - 'class' is a container for code (you'll learn more later)
   - 'HelloWorld' is the name we chose
   - '{' opens a block of code

2. 'public static void main(String[] args) {'
   - This is the 'main method'‚Äîthe entry point where your program starts
   - Don't worry about the details yet, just know: every program needs this line

3. 'System.out.println("Hello, World!");'
   - 'System.out.println' means "print this on the screen"
   - The text inside quotes is what gets printed
   - The semicolon ';' ends the instruction (like a period ends a sentence)

4. The closing braces '}' close the blocks we opened

KEY RULE: Java is case-sensitive. 'System' and 'system' are different. Be precise!

lessons.title: Lesson 0.3: Understanding Variables

contentSections.title: The Problem: The Computer's Memory
contentSections.content:
You've written your first program that prints text. But what if you want the program to REMEMBER something? What if you need to store a number, do some math, and then use that result later?

Right now, your programs are like sticky notes‚Äîthey can display a message, but they can't remember anything. To write useful programs, you need the ability to STORE information.

This is where variables come in.

contentSections.title: Variables are Labeled Boxes
contentSections.content:
Imagine you have a storage room with boxes. Each box:

1. Has a LABEL on it (the variable name) like 'age' or 'score'
2. Can hold ONE thing inside (the value)
3. You can CHANGE what's inside anytime
4. You can LOOK inside to see what's stored

Example:
- Box labeled 'playerScore' contains: 100
- Box labeled 'playerName' contains: 'Alex'
- Box labeled 'isGameOver' contains: false

In Java, when you create a variable, you're saying:
"Computer, create a box, label it with this name, and put this value inside."

The computer reserves a tiny spot in its memory (RAM) for that box.

contentSections.title: Creating Variables in Java
contentSections.content:
To create a variable, you need THREE things:

1. TYPE: What kind of data will the box hold? (number? text? true/false?)
2. NAME: What should we call this box?
3. VALUE: What should we put inside?

The syntax:
type name = value;

Examples:

int age = 25;
  ‚Üë    ‚Üë    ‚Üë
 type name value

Breaking it down:
- 'int' means 'integer' (a whole number)
- 'age' is the name we chose
- '25' is the value we're storing
- ';' ends the statement (like a period)

More examples:
int score = 100;           // Whole number
double price = 19.99;      // Decimal number
String name = "Alice";    // Text (must use quotes!)
boolean isActive = true;   // true or false

Key rule: Once you declare a variable with a type, that box can ONLY hold that type of data.

contentSections.title: Using Variables
contentSections.content:
Once you create a variable, you can:

1. PRINT IT:
   int age = 25;
   System.out.println(age);  // Prints: 25

2. CHANGE IT:
   age = 30;  // Now the box contains 30

3. DO MATH WITH IT:
   int score = 100;
   score = score + 10;  // Now score is 110

4. COMBINE IT WITH TEXT:
   System.out.println("Your score is: " + score);
   // Prints: Your score is: 110

The '+' symbol does different things:
- With numbers: adds them (5 + 3 = 8)
- With text: joins them ("Hello" + "World" = "HelloWorld")

contentSections.title: Variable Naming Rules
contentSections.content:
You can name variables almost anything, BUT:

‚úì DO:
- Use descriptive names: 'playerScore' not 'x'
- Start with a lowercase letter: 'score', 'myAge'
- Use camelCase for multiple words: 'highScore', 'userName'

‚úó DON'T:
- Use spaces: 'my age' is WRONG, use 'myAge'
- Start with a number: '2cool' is WRONG, use 'cool2'
- Use special characters: 'score$' is usually wrong
- Use Java keywords: 'int', 'class', 'public' are reserved

Good names: age, playerScore, userName, totalCost
Bad names: a, x, asdfghjkl, thing123

lessons.title: Lesson 0.4: Making Decisions with If/Else

contentSections.title: The Problem: Programs That Adapt
contentSections.content:
So far, your programs do the same thing every time. They print the same message, calculate the same numbers. But what if you need a program that ADAPTS based on the situation?

Examples:
- A game that says "You win!" if score > 100, but "Try again" if score < 100
- A program that checks if you're old enough to vote
- A calculator that prevents division by zero

You need a way to make the computer ASK A QUESTION and then DO DIFFERENT THINGS based on the answer.

This is called CONDITIONAL LOGIC, and in Java, we use 'if' statements.

contentSections.title: If Statements are Like a Fork in the Road
If Statement Syntax
Adding 'Else' for Two Paths
Comparison Operators
contentSections.content:
To write conditions, you need to compare values. Java has these operators:

==  (equals)              5 == 5  ‚Üí true
!=  (not equals)          5 != 3  ‚Üí true
>   (greater than)        7 > 3   ‚Üí true
<   (less than)           3 < 7   ‚Üí true
>=  (greater or equal)    5 >= 5  ‚Üí true
<=  (less or equal)       3 <= 7  ‚Üí true

‚ö†Ô∏è WARNING: A common mistake!
- Use '==' to COMPARE: if (age == 18)
- Use '=' to ASSIGN: age = 18

if (age = 18) is WRONG! (You're assigning, not comparing)
if (age == 18) is CORRECT!

lessons.title: Lesson 1.1: Data Types in Depth

contentSections.title: The Problem: Different Kinds of Information
contentSections.content:
You've learned that variables store information. But not all information is the same:

‚Ä¢ Your age: a whole number (25)
‚Ä¢ Your bank balance: a decimal number (1,234.56)
‚Ä¢ Your name: text ("Alice")
‚Ä¢ Whether you're logged in: true or false

Java needs to know WHAT KIND of data each variable holds because:
1. Different types use different amounts of memory
2. Different types support different operations (you can't multiply text!)
3. This prevents bugs (accidentally treating a number as text)

Think of it like containers: you wouldn't store soup in a paper bag or carry books in a bucket. The container (type) must match what you're storing (data).

contentSections.title: Data Types are Like Kitchen Containers
contentSections.content:
In a kitchen, you have different containers for different things:

ü•õ Glass (int) - For whole items: 5 apples, 12 eggs, 100 cookies
   Can't hold half items. Either you have 5 apples or 6, not 5.5.

üç∂ Measuring Cup (double) - For liquids: 2.5 cups of water, 1.75 liters
   Can hold precise decimal amounts.

üìù Label Maker (String) - For text: "Flour", "Sugar", "Hello World"
   Stores words and sentences.

üî≤ Checkbox (boolean) - For yes/no: oven on? true/false
   Only two possible values: true or false.

Each container (data type) is designed for a specific purpose!

contentSections.title: The Four Essential Data Types
Type Conversion and Common Mistakes
contentSections.content:
‚ö†Ô∏è Java is STRICT about types:

WRONG:
int x = 3.14;  // ERROR! Can't put decimal in int
String age = 25;  // ERROR! Numbers need quotes to be Strings

CORRECT:
int x = 3;  // Whole number for int
double y = 3.14;  // Decimal for double
String age = "25";  // Text needs quotes

Converting between types:
int age = 25;
String ageText = "" + age;  // Converts to "25"
// OR
String ageText = String.valueOf(age);

double price = 19.99;
int dollars = (int) price;  // Truncates to 19 (loses .99!)

Key rule: Java won't automatically convert if data could be lost.

contentSections.title: Choosing the Right Type
contentSections.content:
How to decide which type to use:

Ask yourself:
1. Is it a number? ‚Üí int or double
   - Whole number? ‚Üí int
   - Needs decimals? ‚Üí double

2. Is it text? ‚Üí String
   - Even if it looks like a number ("123") but you're not doing math

3. Is it yes/no, on/off, true/false? ‚Üí boolean

Examples:
‚úì int numberOfStudents = 30;  // Counting people
‚úì double temperature = 98.6;  // Needs precision
‚úì String username = "alice2024";  // Text identifier
‚úì boolean isValid = true;  // Yes/no flag

‚úó double numberOfStudents = 30.0;  // Wasteful (don't need decimals)
‚úó int price = 20;  // Risky (what about $20.50?)
‚úó String isValid = "true";  // Wrong type (should be boolean)

lessons.title: Lesson 1.2: Operators and Expressions

contentSections.title: The Problem: Doing Math with Variables
contentSections.content:
You can store numbers in variables, but programs need to DO THINGS with those numbers:

‚Ä¢ A calculator adds, subtracts, multiplies, divides
‚Ä¢ A game tracks score: score = score + 10
‚Ä¢ A store calculates total: price * quantity
‚Ä¢ A thermometer converts: fahrenheit = (celsius * 9/5) + 32

Java provides OPERATORS‚Äîsymbols that perform operations on values.

Think of operators as the buttons on a calculator: +, -, √ó, √∑

contentSections.title: Operators are Calculator Buttons
contentSections.content:
Imagine a calculator:

You press: 5 [+] 3 [=]
Result: 8

In Java:
int result = 5 + 3;  // result is 8

The '+' is an OPERATOR. It takes two values (5 and 3) and produces a result (8).

Just like a calculator has buttons for +, -, √ó, √∑, Java has operator symbols:
+ for addition
- for subtraction
* for multiplication (can't use √ó symbol!)
/ for division
% for remainder (modulo)

contentSections.title: The Five Basic Arithmetic Operators
contentSections.content:
1. ADDITION (+)
   int sum = 10 + 5;     // sum is 15
   int x = 7;
   int y = 3;
   int total = x + y;    // total is 10

2. SUBTRACTION (-)
   int difference = 10 - 5;  // 5
   int age = 30;
   int yearsAgo = age - 10;  // 20

3. MULTIPLICATION (*)
   int product = 10 * 5;     // 50
   int price = 20;
   int quantity = 3;
   int total = price * quantity;  // 60

4. DIVISION (/)
   int quotient = 10 / 5;    // 2
   ‚ö†Ô∏è WARNING: int division truncates decimals!
   int result = 10 / 3;      // 3 (not 3.333...)
   double result = 10.0 / 3; // 3.333...

5. MODULO (%) - Remainder after division
   int remainder = 10 % 3;   // 1 (10 √∑ 3 = 3 remainder 1)
   int rem = 17 % 5;         // 2 (17 √∑ 5 = 3 remainder 2)
   Use cases: Check if even (x % 2 == 0), cycle through values

contentSections.title: Order of Operations (PEMDAS)
contentSections.content:
Just like in math, Java follows order of operations:

Parentheses ‚Üí Multiplication/Division ‚Üí Addition/Subtraction

Examples:
int result = 5 + 3 * 2;     // 11 (not 16!)
// Multiply first: 3 * 2 = 6, then add: 5 + 6 = 11

int result = (5 + 3) * 2;   // 16
// Parentheses first: 5 + 3 = 8, then multiply: 8 * 2 = 16

int result = 10 / 2 + 3;    // 8
// Divide first: 10 / 2 = 5, then add: 5 + 3 = 8

When in doubt, use parentheses to be explicit:
int total = (price * quantity) + tax;  // Clear intent

contentSections.title: Shorthand Operators
Common Mistakes to Avoid
contentSections.content:
‚ùå WRONG: int result = 5 x 3;  (x is not an operator)
‚úì CORRECT: int result = 5 * 3;

‚ùå WRONG: int half = 10 / 2.0;  (can't assign double to int)
‚úì CORRECT: double half = 10 / 2.0;

‚ùå WRONG: int result = 10 / 3;  // Thinking this gives 3.33
‚úì CORRECT: double result = 10.0 / 3.0;  // This gives 3.33

‚ùå WRONG: x =+ 5;  (This assigns 5, doesn't add!)
‚úì CORRECT: x += 5;  (This adds 5 to x)

Remember: In integer division, the decimal part is thrown away!
7 / 2 = 3 (not 3.5)

lessons.title: Lesson 1.3: While Loops - Mastering Repetition

contentSections.title: The Problem: Repeating Tasks
contentSections.content:
Imagine you need to print "Hello" 100 times. You COULD write:

System.out.println("Hello");
System.out.println("Hello");
System.out.println("Hello");
// ...97 more times!

This is:
‚ùå Tedious to write
‚ùå Error-prone (did you type exactly 100?)
‚ùå Hard to change (what if you need 1000?)

Real-world examples of repetition:
‚Ä¢ A game runs the same game loop thousands of times
‚Ä¢ A server checks for new requests continuously
‚Ä¢ You scroll through a list of items one by one

You need a way to say: "KEEP DOING THIS until a condition is met."

This is what LOOPS do!

contentSections.title: Loops are Like "Simon Says" Rules
While Loop Syntax
The Infinite Loop Danger
contentSections.content:
‚ö†Ô∏è CRITICAL MISTAKE: Forgetting to change the condition

WRONG:
int count = 1;
while (count <= 5) {
    System.out.println(count);
    // Forgot count++!
}

This creates an INFINITE LOOP:
- count is always 1
- 1 <= 5 is always true
- Loop runs FOREVER
- Your program hangs/crashes

GOLDEN RULE: Always modify the loop variable inside the loop!

Common patterns:
‚Ä¢ Counting up: count++
‚Ä¢ Counting down: count--
‚Ä¢ Reading input: get next value from user

contentSections.title: The Problem: While Loops for Counting Feel Clunky
For Loops are Like a Recipe's Prep List
For Loop Syntax
contentSections.content:
for (initialization; condition; update) {
    // Code to repeat
}

Three parts separated by semicolons:

1. INITIALIZATION: Run once at the start
   int i = 0  (Create counter, set starting value)

2. CONDITION: Check before each iteration
   i < 10  (Keep going while this is true)

3. UPDATE: Run after each iteration
   i++  (Change the counter)

Example - Print 0 to 4:

for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) {
    System.out.println(i);
}

Execution flow:
1. int i = 0  (i is 0)
2. Check: i < 5? YES ‚Üí run code (print 0)
3. Update: i++ (i is now 1)
4. Check: i < 5? YES ‚Üí run code (print 1)
5. Update: i++ (i is now 2)
... continues until i is 5
6. Check: i < 5? NO ‚Üí stop

Output: 0 1 2 3 4

contentSections.title: Common For Loop Patterns
While vs For: When to Use Each
contentSections.content:
Use FOR when:
‚úì You know how many times to loop
‚úì You're counting or iterating
‚úì You have a clear start, end, and step

for (int i = 0; i < 100; i++) { ... }  // "Do this 100 times"

Use WHILE when:
‚úì You DON'T know how many times to loop
‚úì The condition is complex
‚úì Not necessarily counting

while (userWantsMore) { ... }  // "Keep going until user says stop"

Rule of thumb:
Counting ‚Üí for
Condition-based ‚Üí while

contentSections.content:
Imagine you're building a student management system. Each student has:
- name (String)
- age (int)
- gpa (double)

For 100 students, you'd need:

‚ùå Error-prone (easy to mix up which age belongs to which student)
‚ùå Can't use loops or methods effectively

You need a way to group related data together and create your OWN data types.

This is what CLASSES do!

contentSections.title: Classes are Blueprints, Objects are Houses
contentSections.content:
Think of building houses:

BLUEPRINT (Class):
- Defines what a house HAS: rooms, doors, windows
- Defines what a house DOES: open door, turn on lights
- You can't live in a blueprint!

ACTUAL HOUSE (Object):
- Built FROM the blueprint
- Has actual values: 3 bedrooms, blue door, 5 windows
- You can interact with it

From ONE blueprint, you can build MANY houses, each with different colors, sizes, etc.

In Java:
- Class = Blueprint (you define it once)
- Object = Actual instance (you create many from the blueprint)

class Student { } // This is the blueprint
Student alice = new Student(); // This is an actual object

OBJECT:

‚úì Has actual data values

lessons.title: Lesson 2.3: Encapsulation - Protecting Your Data

contentSections.title: The Problem: Anyone Can Mess With Your Objects
Encapsulation is Like a Bank Account
contentSections.content:
WITHOUT ENCAPSULATION:
= Money sitting in a box on your desk
- Anyone can take money out
- Anyone can add fake money
- No security or validation

WITH ENCAPSULATION:
= Money in a bank account
- You can't directly touch the money
- Must use deposit() method (validates amount)
- Must use withdraw() method (checks balance)
- Bank controls access and enforces rules

In Java:
- Fields = private (like money in vault)
- Methods = public (like bank teller window)
- Methods validate before changing fields

contentSections.title: Access Modifiers: public, private, protected
contentSections.content:
Java has keywords that control WHO can access your code:

1. PUBLIC - Anyone can access
   public int speed;  // Any code anywhere can read/write

2. PRIVATE - Only THIS class can access
   private int speed;  // Only methods inside Car can access

3. PROTECTED - This class + subclasses (we'll learn later)

4. DEFAULT (no keyword) - Same package only

BEST PRACTICE:
- Fields: ALWAYS private
- Methods: public if others need them, private if internal only

contentSections.title: Getters and Setters: Controlled Access
Why Encapsulation Matters
contentSections.content:
1. DATA VALIDATION
   - Prevent invalid states (negative speed, empty names)
   - Enforce business rules

2. FLEXIBILITY
   - Change internal implementation without breaking other code
   - Example: Change from int to double, only modify inside class

3. DEBUGGING
   - Put breakpoints in setters to find who's changing data
   - Add logging to track changes

4. SECURITY
   - Hide sensitive data
   - Control who can modify critical fields

Professional code ALWAYS uses encapsulation!

lessons.title: Lesson 2.5: Polymorphism - One Interface, Many Forms

contentSections.title: The Problem: Different Animals Make Different Sounds
Polymorphism is Like a Universal Remote
contentSections.content:
UNIVERSAL REMOTE:
- Has a "Power" button
- Works for TV, DVD player, sound system
- SAME button, DIFFERENT behavior depending on device

POLYMORPHISM IN JAVA:
Animal[] animals = {new Dog(), new Cat(), new Bird()};

for (Animal a : animals) {
    a.makeSound();  // SAME method call
}

Output:
Woof!  (Dog's version)
Meow!  (Cat's version)
Chirp!  (Bird's version)

ONE interface (makeSound), MANY forms (each animal's unique sound).
That's poly (many) + morph (forms) = polymorphism!

contentSections.title: Method Overriding with @Override
Polymorphism in Action
contentSections.content:
The MAGIC of polymorphism:

Animal myPet = new Dog();  // Dog IS-A Animal
myPet.makeSound();  // Calls Dog's version ‚Üí "Woof!"

myPet = new Cat();  // Now it's a Cat
myPet.makeSound();  // Calls Cat's version ‚Üí "Meow!"

This enables POWERFUL patterns:

void feedAnimal(Animal a) {
    System.out.println("Feeding...");
    a.makeSound();  // Will call the RIGHT version automatically!
}

feedAnimal(new Dog());  // "Feeding..." then "Woof!"
feedAnimal(new Cat());  // "Feeding..." then "Meow!"
feedAnimal(new Bird());  // "Feeding..." then "Chirp!"

ONE method works with ALL Animal types!

contentSections.title: Dynamic Method Dispatch
contentSections.content:
HOW does Java know which version to call?

Animal a = new Dog();
a.makeSound();  // Which makeSound()?

Java uses DYNAMIC DISPATCH (runtime polymorphism):
1. Looks at the ACTUAL object type (Dog)
2. Finds the method in Dog's class
3. Calls Dog's version, not Animal's

This happens at RUNTIME, not compile time!

KEY INSIGHT:
- Variable type (Animal) determines WHAT methods are available
- Object type (Dog) determines WHICH version gets called

This is the foundation of flexible, extensible code!

contentSections.content:
Remember our Animal example?

class Animal {
    public void makeSound() {
        System.out.println("Generic sound");  // What IS a generic sound?

Problems:
1. There's no such thing as a "generic animal" - it's too abstract
2. What if someone creates: Animal a = new Animal()?

contentSections.title: Abstract Classes: Templates with Rules

contentSections.content:
ABSTRACT CLASS = Recipe template with mandatory steps:

Recipe Template:
1. Prepare batter (ABSTRACT - each cake type does it differently)
2. Pour into pan (CONCRETE - same for all cakes)
3. Bake (CONCRETE - same for all)
4. Decorate (ABSTRACT - each cake type unique)

You can't make a "generic cake" from the template.
You must make: Chocolate Cake, Vanilla Cake, etc.
Each MUST specify how to prepare batter and decorate.

abstract class Recipe {  // Can't instantiate
    abstract void prepareBatter();  // MUST implement
    void pourIntoPan() { ... }  // Inherited as-is
    void bake() { ... }  // Inherited as-is
    abstract void decorate();  // MUST implement
}

class ChocolateCake extends Recipe {
    void prepareBatter() { /* chocolate batter */ }
    void decorate() { /* chocolate frosting */ }
}

contentSections.title: The Problem: Fixed-Size Arrays
contentSections.content:
Remember arrays?

int[] numbers = new int[5];  // Size is FIXED at 5

Problems:
1. What if you need to add a 6th element? Can't do it!
2. What if you need to remove an element? Have to shift manually
3. No built-in methods for common operations

Example:
You're building a to-do list app. How many tasks will users have?
- Could be 0
- Could be 5
- Could be 100

You CAN'T predict the size!

Solution: ArrayList - a dynamic, resizable array!

contentSections.title: ArrayList is Like an Accordion Folder
contentSections.content:
FIXED ARRAY:
= Box with 5 compartments
- Can hold exactly 5 items
- Want to add a 6th? Too bad!
- Want to remove one? Empty slot remains

ARRAYLIST:
= Accordion folder
- Starts with some capacity
- Add items ‚Üí expands automatically
- Remove items ‚Üí shrinks, no gaps
- Has methods: add(), remove(), get(), size()

ArrayList handles resizing for you!

contentSections.title: ArrayList Syntax and Operations
contentSections.content:
IMPORT:
import java.util.ArrayList;

CREATING:
ArrayList<String> names = new ArrayList<>();
// <String> = type parameter (ArrayList of Strings)

ADDING ELEMENTS:
names.add("Alice");  // ["Alice"]
names.add("Bob");    // ["Alice", "Bob"]
names.add("Carol");  // ["Alice", "Bob", "Carol"]

ACCESSING:
names.get(0);  // "Alice" (like array[0])
names.get(1);  // "Bob"

SIZE:

REMOVING:
names.remove(1);  // Remove "Bob"
// Now: ["Alice", "Carol"] - automatically shifts!

CHECKING:

lessons.title: Lesson 3.3: HashMap - Looking Up by Name

contentSections.title: The Problem: Finding Data by Index is Limiting
contentSections.content:
With ArrayList, you access by INDEX:

ArrayList<String> students = new ArrayList<>();
students.add("Alice");  // index 0
students.add("Bob");    // index 1

To find Bob, you need to:
- Loop through entire list
- Check each name
- Remember which index was Bob

Real-world scenarios:
- Look up a phone number by NAME (not position)
- Find product price by SKU code
- Get user profile by username

You need: KEY ‚Üí VALUE lookup

Solution: HashMap!

contentSections.title: HashMap is Like a Dictionary
contentSections.content:
ENGLISH DICTIONARY:
- Look up "apple" (KEY)
- Get definition: "a round fruit..." (VALUE)
- Don't need to know page number
- Direct lookup!

JAVA HASHMAP:
HashMap<String, String> phonebook = new HashMap<>();
phonebook.put("Alice", "555-1234");  // KEY ‚Üí VALUE
phonebook.put("Bob", "555-5678");

String aliceNumber = phonebook.get("Alice");  // "555-1234"

Fast lookup by KEY, not index!

contentSections.title: HashMap Syntax and Operations
contentSections.content:
IMPORT:
import java.util.HashMap;

CREATING:
HashMap<String, Integer> ages = new HashMap<>();
// <KeyType, ValueType>

ADDING/UPDATING:
ages.put("Alice", 25);  // Add Alice ‚Üí 25
ages.put("Bob", 30);    // Add Bob ‚Üí 30
ages.put("Alice", 26);  // UPDATE Alice to 26 (overwrites)

GETTING VALUES:
ages.get("Alice");  // 26
ages.get("Bob");    // 30
ages.get("Carol");  // null (not found)

CHECKING:
ages.containsKey("Alice");  // true
ages.containsValue(30);  // true
ages.isEmpty();  // false

REMOVING:
ages.remove("Bob");  // Remove Bob's entry

SIZE:
ages.size();  // 1 (only Alice remains)

contentSections.title: Looping Through a HashMap
HashMap Performance and Use Cases
contentSections.content:
PERFORMANCE:
- put(key, value): O(1) average - FAST!
- get(key): O(1) average - FAST!
- containsKey(key): O(1) average - FAST!

Compare to ArrayList search: O(n) - must check every element

WHEN TO USE HASHMAP:
‚úì Need fast lookup by key
‚úì Key-value associations (username ‚Üí profile)
‚úì Counting occurrences (word ‚Üí count)
‚úì Caching results (input ‚Üí output)

WHEN NOT TO USE:
‚úó Need to maintain order (use LinkedHashMap)
‚úó Need sorting (use TreeMap)
‚úó Just storing a list of items (use ArrayList)

lessons.title: Lesson 3.4: LinkedList - A Different Kind of List

contentSections.title: The Problem: ArrayList Insertion is Slow
contentSections.content:
ArrayList stores elements in a continuous block:

[0] [1] [2] [3] [4]

What happens when you INSERT in the middle?

list.add(2, "NEW");  // Insert at index 2

ArrayList must:
1. Shift element at index 2 to index 3
2. Shift element at index 3 to index 4
3. Shift element at index 4 to index 5
4. THEN insert "NEW" at index 2

For 1 million elements, this is SLOW! O(n) time

LinkedList solves this differently!

contentSections.title: LinkedList is Like a Chain of People Holding Hands
contentSections.content:
ARRAYLIST:
= People standing in numbered spots
[Person 0] [Person 1] [Person 2] [Person 3]
- To add someone in middle: everyone shifts spots
- Access by position: very fast (just go to spot 2)

LINKEDLIST:
= Chain of people holding hands
(Alice) ‚Üí (Bob) ‚Üí (Carol) ‚Üí (Dave)
- Each person holds hand of next person
- To insert: break one handhold, insert new person, reconnect
- Access by position: must walk from start (slower)

LinkedList: Fast insertion, slower access
ArrayList: Slower insertion, fast access

contentSections.title: LinkedList Syntax
contentSections.content:
IMPORT:
import java.util.LinkedList;

CREATING:
LinkedList<String> names = new LinkedList<>();

LinkedList has ALL ArrayList methods:
names.add("Alice");
names.add("Bob");
names.get(0);  // "Alice"
names.remove(1);  // Remove Bob

PLUS special methods for ends:
names.addFirst("First");  // Add to beginning
names.addLast("Last");    // Add to end
names.getFirst();  // Get first element
names.getLast();   // Get last element
names.removeFirst();  // Remove first
names.removeLast();   // Remove last

These operations are O(1) - VERY FAST!

contentSections.title: ArrayList vs LinkedList: Performance Comparison
contentSections.content:
OPERATION          | ArrayList | LinkedList
-------------------|-----------|-----------
get(index)         | O(1) ‚úì    | O(n) ‚úó
add(element)       | O(1) ‚úì    | O(1) ‚úì
add(index, elem)   | O(n) ‚úó    | O(n) ~
addFirst(elem)     | O(n) ‚úó    | O(1) ‚úì
addLast(elem)      | O(1) ‚úì    | O(1) ‚úì
remove(index)      | O(n) ‚úó    | O(n) ~
removeFirst()      | O(n) ‚úó    | O(1) ‚úì
removeLast()       | O(1) ‚úì    | O(1) ‚úì

O(1) = Constant time (FAST)
O(n) = Linear time (scales with size)

SUMMARY:
ArrayList: Fast random access, slow insertions
LinkedList: Slow random access, fast insertions at ends

contentSections.title: When to Use Each Collection
contentSections.content:
USE ARRAYLIST WHEN:
‚úì You access elements by index frequently
‚úì You mostly add to the end
‚úì You iterate through all elements
‚úì MOST COMMON USE CASE (default choice)

Example: Displaying a list of products

USE LINKEDLIST WHEN:
‚úì You frequently insert/remove at the beginning
‚úì You implement a Queue (FIFO)
‚úì You implement a Stack (LIFO)
‚úì You rarely access by index

Example: Task queue where tasks are added/removed from front

USE HASHMAP WHEN:
‚úì You need key-value pairs
‚úì You need fast lookup by key
‚úì Order doesn't matter

Example: User profiles by username

RULE OF THUMB: Start with ArrayList unless you have a reason not to!

lessons.title: Lesson 4.1: Why Test Your Code?

contentSections.title: The Problem: How Do You Know It Works?
contentSections.content:
You've written a method:

public static int add(int a, int b) {
    return a + b;
}

How do you KNOW it works correctly for all inputs?
- What if a is negative?
- What if both are zero?
- What if they're very large numbers?

Manual testing (running main and checking output) is:
‚ùå Tedious
‚ùå Error-prone
‚ùå Doesn't scale

Professional developers write AUTOMATED TESTS that run instantly and check everything.

contentSections.title: Tests are Like a Parachute
contentSections.content:
Would you jump out of a plane with a parachute you've never tested?

Same with code:
- Tests verify your code works
- They catch bugs BEFORE users see them
- They give you confidence to make changes

A well-tested codebase is like a safety net.

contentSections.title: The Anatomy of a JUnit Test
Common Assertion Methods
Tests are Like Scientific Experiments
Test Naming Conventions
contentSections.content:
GOOD TEST NAMES describe WHAT is being tested:

‚ùå Bad names:
test1()
testStuff()
myTest()

‚úì Good names:
testAddPositiveNumbers()
testDivideByZeroThrowsException()
testEmptyListReturnsZero()

PATTERN:
test[MethodName][Scenario][ExpectedResult]

Examples:
testCalculateDiscountWithValidCouponReturnsReducedPrice()
testGetUserWithInvalidIdReturnsNull()
testSortEmptyArrayReturnsEmptyArray()

Good names make it OBVIOUS what broke when a test fails!

contentSections.title: üíª Real Test Class Example
‚ö†Ô∏è Don't Test Everything - Test What Matters
contentSections.content:
‚ùå Don't test:
- Getters/setters (trivial code)
- External libraries (already tested)
- UI code (use different techniques)

‚úì DO test:
- Business logic
- Complex calculations
- Edge cases (empty lists, null values, boundaries)
- Error handling

AIM FOR: 70-80% code coverage
NOT: 100% (diminishing returns, wastes time)

lessons.title: Lesson 4.3: Test-Driven Development - Write Tests First!

contentSections.title: The Traditional Approach (and Its Problems)
contentSections.content:
TYPICAL development workflow:

1. Write code
2. Run it, see if it works
3. Find bugs
4. Fix bugs
5. Maybe write tests later (if you have time)

PROBLEMS:
‚ùå Tests are an afterthought
‚ùå You might forget edge cases
‚ùå Code might be hard to test (not designed for it)
‚ùå Tests often get skipped ("no time")

What if there was a BETTER way?

contentSections.title: Test-Driven Development (TDD) - A Revolutionary Approach
TDD is Like Building with a Blueprint
contentSections.content:
BUILDING WITHOUT BLUEPRINT (traditional):
- Start nailing boards together
- Hope it looks like a house
- Realize door is in wrong place
- Tear down, rebuild

BUILDING WITH BLUEPRINT (TDD):
- Draw blueprint first (the test)
- Blueprint shows exactly what you need
- Build to match blueprint
- Verify it matches blueprint

TDD TESTS = Blueprints for your code
They specify EXACTLY what the code should do BEFORE you write it.

contentSections.title: Benefits of TDD
contentSections.content:
1. FEWER BUGS
   - Tests written first catch issues immediately
   - You think through edge cases upfront

2. BETTER DESIGN
   - Code is automatically testable
   - Forces you to write modular, decoupled code

3. LIVING DOCUMENTATION
   - Tests show how to use your code
   - Examples of every feature

4. CONFIDENCE TO REFACTOR
   - Change code freely
   - Tests verify nothing broke

5. LESS DEBUGGING
   - Catch bugs in seconds, not hours
   - Know exactly what's broken

Professional developers use TDD for critical code.

contentSections.title: üíª TDD Example: Building a Password Validator
‚ö†Ô∏è Common TDD Mistakes
contentSections.content:
‚ùå Writing too much code at once
   - Only write code to pass the CURRENT test

‚ùå Skipping the refactor step
   - Clean code is as important as working code

‚ùå Testing implementation details
   - Test BEHAVIOR, not internal structure

‚ùå Not running tests frequently
   - Run tests after every small change

‚ùå Writing tests that depend on each other
   - Each test should be independent

‚úì Good TDD: Small steps, frequent feedback

lessons.title: Lesson 4.4: Maven - Managing Projects Like a Pro

contentSections.title: The Problem: Managing Dependencies Manually is a Nightmare
contentSections.content:
Imagine building a real project:

You need external libraries:
- JUnit for testing
- Gson for JSON parsing
- Apache Commons for utilities

Manual approach:
1. Download each JAR file from the internet
2. Put them in your project folder
3. Add to classpath manually
4. What if library needs OTHER libraries?
5. What if versions conflict?
6. How do teammates get same libraries?

This is CHAOS! Welcome to dependency hell.

Solution: BUILD TOOLS like Maven

contentSections.title: What is Maven?
contentSections.content:
MAVEN is a build automation tool that:

‚úì Manages dependencies (downloads libraries)
‚úì Compiles your code
‚úì Runs tests
‚úì Packages your app (creates JAR file)
‚úì Enforces standard project structure

Instead of:
- "Download JUnit JAR"
- "Add to classpath"
- "Hope it works"

You write in pom.xml:
<dependency>
    <groupId>junit</groupId>
    <artifactId>junit</artifactId>
    <version>5.9.3</version>
</dependency>

Maven downloads it automatically! ‚ú®

contentSections.title: Maven is Like a Restaurant Manager
contentSections.content:
WITHOUT MAVEN (You're a cook doing everything):
- Buy ingredients yourself
- Track which suppliers have what
- Check if ingredients are compatible
- Organize kitchen yourself
- Cook AND manage

WITH MAVEN (Restaurant manager):
- You tell manager: "I need tomatoes, version 2.0"
- Manager orders from suppliers
- Manager organizes kitchen layout
- Manager ensures everything's in the right place
- You just focus on cooking (coding)

Maven handles the boring project management stuff!

contentSections.title: Maven Project Structure
contentSections.content:
Maven enforces a STANDARD structure:

my-project/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ pom.xml                 (Project config file)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ main/
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ java/          (Your application code)
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ com/yourcompany/App.java
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ resources/     (Config files, properties)
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ test/
‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ java/          (Your test code)
‚îÇ       ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ com/yourcompany/AppTest.java
‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ resources/     (Test resources)
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ target/                 (Compiled output - Maven creates this)

BENEFITS:
‚úì Every Maven project looks the same
‚úì New developers know where everything is
‚úì Tools work automatically

This is "Convention Over Configuration"

contentSections.title: The pom.xml File - Project Object Model
contentSections.content:
pom.xml is the heart of a Maven project:

<project>
    <groupId>com.yourcompany</groupId>
    <artifactId>my-app</artifactId>
    <version>1.0.0</version>
    
    <properties>
        <maven.compiler.source>17</maven.compiler.source>
        <maven.compiler.target>17</maven.compiler.target>
    </properties>
    
    <dependencies>
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.junit.jupiter</groupId>
            <artifactId>junit-jupiter</artifactId>
            <version>5.9.3</version>
            <scope>test</scope>
        </dependency>
    </dependencies>
</project>

KEY SECTIONS:
- groupId: Your organization (like package)
- artifactId: Project name
- version: Your project version
- properties: Configuration (Java version, etc.)
- dependencies: External libraries you need

contentSections.title: Common Maven Commands
contentSections.content:
Run these from command line in project folder:

mvn clean
  ‚Üí Deletes target/ folder (compiled output)

mvn compile
  ‚Üí Compiles your main source code

mvn test
  ‚Üí Compiles and runs all tests

mvn package
  ‚Üí Compiles, tests, and creates JAR file

mvn install
  ‚Üí Package and install to local repository

mvn clean test
  ‚Üí Clean then test (combines commands)

MOST COMMON WORKFLOW:
1. Write code
2. mvn clean test (verify tests pass)
3. mvn package (create JAR)
4. Deploy JAR to production

contentSections.title: Maven Dependency Scopes
contentSections.content:
SCOPE controls WHEN a dependency is available:

<scope>compile</scope> (default)
  - Available everywhere (main code, tests, runtime)
  - Example: Gson JSON library

<scope>test</scope>
  - Only for tests, not in final JAR
  - Example: JUnit

<scope>provided</scope>
  - Available at compile-time, but server provides it at runtime
  - Example: Servlet API (server like Tomcat has it)

<scope>runtime</scope>
  - Not needed for compilation, only at runtime
  - Example: JDBC database driver

RULE: Use test scope for testing libraries (saves space in final JAR)

lessons.title: Lesson 4.5: Debugging, Logging, and Professional Habits

contentSections.title: The Problem: System.out.println() Everywhere
contentSections.content:
Beginner debugging:

public void processOrder(Order order) {
    System.out.println("Got order: " + order);  // Debug line
    calculateTotal(order);
    System.out.println("Total: " + order.getTotal());  // Debug line

‚ùå Forgot to remove debug prints before release
‚ùå No timestamps or context

Professional solution: LOGGING FRAMEWORKS

contentSections.title: Logging with SLF4J and Logback
Using a Debugger - The Professional's Tool
contentSections.content:
Instead of println, use your IDE's DEBUGGER:

KEY FEATURES:

1. BREAKPOINTS
   - Click next to line number (red dot appears)
   - Program PAUSES when it reaches that line
   - Inspect ALL variables at that moment

2. STEP THROUGH CODE
   - Step Over: Execute current line, move to next

   - Step Out: Finish current method, return to caller

3. WATCH VARIABLES

4. CALL STACK

   - Navigate to any point

DEBUGGING WORKFLOW:
1. Set breakpoint where problem might be
2. Run in debug mode
3. When paused, inspect variables
4. Step through code line by line
5. Watch how values change
6. Identify where logic goes wrong

contentSections.title: Logging vs Debugging
contentSections.content:
LOGGING = Security cameras:
- Always recording
- Review footage after incident
- See what happened over time
- Good for: production issues, patterns

Example:
"Why did the server crash at 3am?"
‚Üí Check logs for ERROR messages at that time

DEBUGGING = Live investigation:
- Stop and examine everything NOW
- Step-by-step analysis
- Immediate feedback
- Good for: development, understanding flow

Example:
"Why is calculateTotal() returning wrong value?"
‚Üí Set breakpoint, inspect variables, step through logic

USE BOTH!

lessons.title: Lesson 5.1: Why Do We Need Databases?

contentSections.title: The Problem: Data Disappears
contentSections.content:
Your program can store data in variables and arrays:

ArrayList<Student> students = new ArrayList<>();
students.add(new Student("Alice", 20));

But when the program ends... POOF! All data is gone.

Next time you run it, you start from scratch.

Real applications need PERSISTENCE:
- User accounts must survive restarts
- Orders must be saved
- Posts, messages, files must persist

This is why we need DATABASES.

contentSections.title: Databases are Like Libraries
contentSections.content:
Your program's memory (variables) = Your desk
- Fast access
- Limited space
- Temporary (clear when you leave)

A database = A library
- Massive storage
- Organized (card catalog)
- Permanent (survives computer shutdowns)
- Shared (multiple programs can access)

You work with data on your desk (RAM), but save important things to the library (database).

contentSections.title: SQL - The Database Language

lessons.title: Lesson 5.2: SQL Basics - Your First Database

contentSections.title: Creating a Table - The Foundation
contentSections.content:
Before storing data, you need a TABLE (like a spreadsheet):

CREATE TABLE students (
    id INT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT,
    name VARCHAR(100) NOT NULL,
    age INT,
    email VARCHAR(255) UNIQUE,
    gpa DECIMAL(3, 2)
);

BREAKING IT DOWN:
- id: Unique identifier for each student
- PRIMARY KEY: This field uniquely identifies each row
- AUTO_INCREMENT: Database automatically assigns 1, 2, 3...
- VARCHAR(100): Text up to 100 characters
- NOT NULL: This field is required (can't be empty)
- UNIQUE: No two students can have the same email
- DECIMAL(3, 2): Numbers like 3.75 (3 total digits, 2 after decimal)

contentSections.title: Common Data Types in SQL
contentSections.content:
TEXT TYPES:
- CHAR(n): Fixed-length text (CHAR(5) for "HELLO")
- VARCHAR(n): Variable-length text (VARCHAR(255) for emails)
- TEXT: Very long text (articles, comments)

NUMBER TYPES:
- INT: Whole numbers (-2147483648 to 2147483647)
- BIGINT: Bigger whole numbers
- DECIMAL(p, s): Exact decimals (DECIMAL(10, 2) for money: 12345678.90)
- FLOAT/DOUBLE: Approximate decimals (scientific calculations)

DATE/TIME TYPES:
- DATE: Just date (2025-01-15)
- TIME: Just time (14:30:00)
- DATETIME: Both (2025-01-15 14:30:00)
- TIMESTAMP: Date + time with timezone

BOOLEAN:
- BOOLEAN: true/false (stored as 0 or 1)

contentSections.title: Inserting Data - Adding Rows
Selecting Data - Querying Tables
Tables are Like Spreadsheets
contentSections.content:
Excel spreadsheet:
| ID | Name          | Age | Email              | GPA  |
|----|---------------|-----|--------------------| -----|
| 1  | Alice Johnson | 20  | alice@example.com  | 3.75 |
| 2  | Bob Smith     | 21  | bob@example.com    | 3.50 |
| 3  | Carol Davis   | 19  | carol@example.com  | 3.90 |

Database table = Same thing!
- Each ROW = One student
- Each COLUMN = One property
- Each CELL = One value

SQL just lets you manipulate this "spreadsheet" with commands.

contentSections.title: Primary Keys - The Unique Identifier
contentSections.content:
Every table should have a PRIMARY KEY:

WHY?
- Uniquely identifies each row
- Prevents duplicate entries
- Allows referencing from other tables

GOOD PRIMARY KEYS:
‚úì id INT AUTO_INCREMENT
‚úì email (if truly unique)
‚úì username (if truly unique)

BAD PRIMARY KEYS:
‚úó name (not unique - many "John Smith"s)
‚úó age (definitely not unique)

BEST PRACTICE:
Always use an auto-incrementing ID as primary key.
Simple, guaranteed unique, fast.

lessons.title: Lesson 5.3: SQL Queries - Filtering, Sorting, and Aggregating

contentSections.title: WHERE Clause - Filtering Rows
contentSections.content:
The WHERE clause filters which rows to return:

COMPARISON OPERATORS:
SELECT * FROM students WHERE age = 21;      // Equal
SELECT * FROM students WHERE age != 21;     // Not equal
SELECT * FROM students WHERE age > 20;      // Greater than
SELECT * FROM students WHERE age >= 20;     // Greater or equal
SELECT * FROM students WHERE age BETWEEN 18 AND 22;

PATTERN MATCHING:
SELECT * FROM students WHERE name LIKE 'A%';      // Starts with A
SELECT * FROM students WHERE email LIKE '%gmail.com';  // Ends with gmail.com
SELECT * FROM students WHERE name LIKE '%son%';   // Contains 'son'

NULL CHECKS:
SELECT * FROM students WHERE email IS NULL;
SELECT * FROM students WHERE email IS NOT NULL;

IN OPERATOR:
SELECT * FROM students WHERE age IN (18, 19, 20);
SELECT * FROM students WHERE name IN ('Alice', 'Bob', 'Carol');

contentSections.title: ORDER BY - Sorting Results
Aggregate Functions - Calculations
GROUP BY - Grouping Results
contentSections.content:
GROUP BY combines rows with same values:

SELECT age, COUNT(*) as student_count
FROM students
GROUP BY age;

Result:
| age | student_count |
|-----|---------------|
| 18  | 5             |
| 19  | 8             |
| 20  | 12            |
| 21  | 7             |

WITH AGGREGATES:
SELECT age, AVG(gpa) as avg_gpa
FROM students
GROUP BY age;

HAVING - Filtering Groups:
SELECT age, COUNT(*) as count
FROM students
GROUP BY age
HAVING count > 5;
// Only show age groups with more than 5 students

NOTE: WHERE filters ROWS, HAVING filters GROUPS

contentSections.title: Query Order Matters!
contentSections.content:
SQL queries are executed in this order:

1. FROM - Which table(s)
2. WHERE - Filter rows
3. GROUP BY - Group rows
4. HAVING - Filter groups
5. SELECT - Choose columns
6. ORDER BY - Sort results
7. LIMIT - Restrict number

Example query using all:

SELECT age, COUNT(*) as count, AVG(gpa) as avg_gpa
FROM students
WHERE email IS NOT NULL
GROUP BY age
HAVING count > 3
ORDER BY avg_gpa DESC
LIMIT 5;

lessons.title: Lesson 5.4: JOINs - Connecting Tables

contentSections.title: The Problem: Data Spread Across Tables
contentSections.content:
Imagine a school database:

students table:
| id | name  | age |
|----|-------|-----|
| 1  | Alice | 20  |
| 2  | Bob   | 21  |

enrollments table:
| id | student_id | course_name     |
|----|------------|----------------|
| 1  | 1          | Math 101        |
| 2  | 1          | Physics 201     |
| 3  | 2          | Math 101        |

How do you find all courses Alice is enrolled in?
You need to CONNECT (JOIN) these tables!

contentSections.title: Foreign Keys - Linking Tables
contentSections.content:
A FOREIGN KEY references another table's PRIMARY KEY:

CREATE TABLE enrollments (
    id INT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT,
    student_id INT,
    course_name VARCHAR(100),
    FOREIGN KEY (student_id) REFERENCES students(id)
);

student_id is a FOREIGN KEY:
- Points to id in students table
- Creates a relationship between tables
- Enforces referential integrity

You can't:
- Add enrollment with student_id = 999 (student doesn't exist)
- Delete a student who has enrollments (without CASCADE)

contentSections.title: INNER JOIN - Matching Rows Only
contentSections.content:
INNER JOIN returns rows that exist in BOTH tables:

SELECT students.name, enrollments.course_name
FROM students
INNER JOIN enrollments ON students.id = enrollments.student_id;

Result:
| name  | course_name |
|-------|-------------|
| Alice | Math 101    |
| Alice | Physics 201 |
| Bob   | Math 101    |

BREAKDOWN:
- FROM students: Start with students table
- INNER JOIN enrollments: Connect to enrollments
- ON students.id = enrollments.student_id: How they connect

Only includes students WHO HAVE enrollments.

contentSections.title: LEFT JOIN - Keep All Left Side Rows
contentSections.content:
LEFT JOIN returns ALL rows from left table, even if no match:

SELECT students.name, enrollments.course_name
FROM students
LEFT JOIN enrollments ON students.id = enrollments.student_id;

If student 'Carol' (id=3) has no enrollments:
| name  | course_name |
|-------|-------------|
| Alice | Math 101    |
| Alice | Physics 201 |
| Bob   | Math 101    |
| Carol | NULL        |  ‚Üê Carol included even with no enrollments

USE CASE:
Find students who haven't enrolled in anything:
SELECT students.name
FROM students
LEFT JOIN enrollments ON students.id = enrollments.student_id
WHERE enrollments.id IS NULL;

contentSections.title: JOINs are Like Matching Puzzle Pieces
contentSections.content:
INNER JOIN = Only matched pieces:
Student ‚ü∑ Enrollment
  üß©‚îÄüß©  (connected)
  üß©‚îÄüß©  (connected)
  üß© (no match, excluded)

LEFT JOIN = Keep all left pieces:
Student ‚Üí Enrollment
  üß©‚îÄüß©  (connected)
  üß©‚îÄüß©  (connected)
  üß©‚îÄ‚ùì  (student kept, enrollment NULL)

Think of LEFT table as the "main" one you want to keep.

contentSections.title: Many-to-Many Relationships
contentSections.content:
SCENARIO: Students can take many courses, courses have many students

BAD DESIGN: Store courses in student table
students:
| id | name  | courses_taken          |
|----|-------|------------------------|
| 1  | Alice | Math 101, Physics 201  |  ‚Üê Hard to query!

GOOD DESIGN: Junction table (join table)

students:
| id | name  |

courses:
| id | course_name |

enrollments (junction table):
| student_id | course_id |
|------------|----------|
| 1          | 101      |
| 1          | 201      |
| 2          | 101      |

THREE-WAY JOIN:
SELECT students.name, courses.course_name
FROM students
INNER JOIN enrollments ON students.id = enrollments.student_id
INNER JOIN courses ON enrollments.course_id = courses.id;

lessons.title: Lesson 5.5: JDBC - Databases + Java

contentSections.title: The Problem: Java Needs to Talk to Databases
contentSections.content:
So far:
- You know Java (objects, methods, classes)
- You know SQL (SELECT, INSERT, JOIN)

But they're separate!

How do you run SQL from Java code?
How do you get query results into Java objects?

Solution: JDBC (Java Database Connectivity)
- Standard Java API for database access
- Works with MySQL, PostgreSQL, Oracle, etc.
- Lets you execute SQL from Java code

contentSections.title: JDBC Connection Steps
Executing Queries - SELECT
Executing Updates - INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE
‚ö†Ô∏è SQL Injection - A Critical Security Risk!
PreparedStatement - The Right Way
JDBC Best Practices
contentSections.content:
1. ALWAYS USE TRY-WITH-RESOURCES
   - Auto-closes connections, statements, resultsets
   - Prevents resource leaks

2. USE PREPAREDSTATEMENT, NOT STATEMENT
   - Security (prevents SQL injection)
   - Performance (pre-compiled)

3. DON'T CONCATENATE SQL WITH USER INPUT
   - Use ? placeholders
   - Set parameters with setString(), setInt(), etc.

4. USE CONNECTION POOLING IN PRODUCTION
   - Libraries: HikariCP, Apache DBCP
   - Reuse connections (expensive to create)

5. HANDLE EXCEPTIONS PROPERLY
   - Log errors
   - Don't expose SQL details to users

6. CLOSE RESOURCES IN FINALLY OR USE TRY-WITH-RESOURCES
   - Connection leaks kill performance

lessons.title: Lesson 6.1: How Does the Web Actually Work?

contentSections.title: The Problem: Programs That Talk Over the Internet
contentSections.content:
So far, your programs run on ONE computer.

But modern apps need to:
- Let users access from anywhere (phone, laptop, tablet)
- Share data between users
- Update in real-time

Example: Instagram
- You post a photo from your phone
- Your friend sees it on their laptop
- How did the photo get there?

This requires CLIENT-SERVER architecture.

contentSections.title: The Web is Like a Restaurant
contentSections.content:
YOU (Client):
- Sit at a table
- Look at menu
- Order food: "I'll have the pasta"

KITCHEN (Server):
- Receives your order
- Prepares the food
- Sends it back to you

WAITER (HTTP Protocol):
- Carries messages between you and kitchen
- Speaks a specific language (HTTP)

In web terms:
- Your browser = Client (customer)
- Java server = Server (kitchen)
- HTTP = Protocol (waiter's language)

contentSections.title: HTTP Requests and Responses
contentSections.content:
When you visit a website:

1. CLIENT SENDS REQUEST:
GET /api/users/123 HTTP/1.1
Host: example.com

This means: "Give me information about user 123"

2. SERVER PROCESSES REQUEST:
- Looks up user 123 in database
- Prepares the data

3. SERVER SENDS RESPONSE:
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: application/json
{"name": "Alice", "age": 20}

Common HTTP methods:
- GET: Retrieve data ("show me")
- POST: Create data ("save this")
- PUT: Update data ("change this")
- DELETE: Remove data ("delete this")

lessons.title: Lesson 6.2: REST APIs - The Standard for Web Services

contentSections.title: What is a REST API?
contentSections.content:
REST = Representational State Transfer

A REST API is a set of rules for building web services:

KEY PRINCIPLES:
1. Resources identified by URLs
2. HTTP methods define actions
3. Stateless (each request independent)
4. JSON for data exchange

EXAMPLE API:
GET    /api/users        ‚Üí Get all users
GET    /api/users/123    ‚Üí Get user with ID 123
POST   /api/users        ‚Üí Create new user
PUT    /api/users/123    ‚Üí Update user 123
DELETE /api/users/123    ‚Üí Delete user 123

contentSections.title: HTTP Methods - The Verbs
contentSections.content:
GET - Retrieve data (read-only, safe):
GET /api/products
Response: [{ "id": 1, "name": "Laptop", "price": 999 }]

POST - Create new resource:
POST /api/products
Body: { "name": "Mouse", "price": 25 }
Response: { "id": 2, "name": "Mouse", "price": 25 }

lessons.title: Lesson 8.5: Deployment - From Laptop to Production

contentSections.title: The Journey from Development to Production
contentSections.content:
Your application works on your laptop. Great!
But how do users actually use it?

THE DEPLOYMENT PIPELINE:

1. DEVELOPMENT (Your laptop):
   - Run: ./mvnw spring-boot:run
   - Database: localhost:5432
   - Hot reload enabled
   - Debug mode on

2. BUILD (Create executable):
   - Package as JAR file
   - All dependencies included
   - Single file to deploy

3. TEST ENVIRONMENT (Pre-production):
   - Test database
   - Similar to production
   - Catch bugs before users see them

4. PRODUCTION (The real thing):
   - Real database with real data
   - Real users
   - Must be reliable, secure, fast
   - Logging and monitoring essential

GOAL: Make deployment smooth, repeatable, and safe!

contentSections.title: Deployment is Like Opening a Restaurant
contentSections.content:
DEVELOPMENT (Test kitchen at home):
You're experimenting with recipes in your home kitchen
Like: Running on localhost, making changes

BUILD (Prepare for opening):
Package all your recipes, ingredients, equipment
Like: mvn package creates myapp.jar

TEST ENVIRONMENT (Soft opening):
Invite friends and family to test the restaurant
Like: Deploy to staging server, run tests

PRODUCTION (Grand opening):
Real customers, real money, real reviews
Like: Deploy to production server, monitor everything

CONFIGURATION:
Home kitchen uses different equipment than restaurant
Like: Dev uses localhost, prod uses real database URL
Solution: Environment variables (swap out settings)

contentSections.title: Building a Production JAR
contentSections.content:
Spring Boot creates a 'fat JAR' - everything in one file:

Build with Maven:
./mvnw clean package

This creates:
target/myapp-0.0.1-SNAPSHOT.jar

Run the JAR:
java -jar target/myapp-0.0.1-SNAPSHOT.jar

What's inside the JAR?
- Your compiled code (.class files)
- All dependencies (Spring, database drivers, etc.)
- Embedded web server (Tomcat)
- Configuration files (application.yml)

RESULT: One file that runs anywhere with Java installed!

Skip tests during build (faster, but risky):
./mvnw clean package -DskipTests

Build with specific profile:
./mvnw clean package -Pprod

Rename JAR to something simpler:
In pom.xml:
<build>
    <finalName>myapp</finalName>
</build>

Now creates: target/myapp.jar

contentSections.title: Environment-Specific Configuration
contentSections.content:
DON'T hardcode production values!

BAD:
spring.datasource.url=jdbc:postgresql://prod-server:5432/db
spring.datasource.password=supersecret123

GOOD: Use Spring Profiles

application.yml (default/shared config):
spring:
  application:
    name: myapp
  jpa:
    hibernate:
      ddl-auto: validate  # Safe default

application-dev.yml (development):
spring:
  datasource:
    url: jdbc:postgresql://localhost:5432/myapp_dev
    username: dev_user
    password: dev_password
  jpa:
    hibernate:
      ddl-auto: create-drop  # Recreate DB each time
    show-sql: true  # Show all SQL queries

application-prod.yml (production):
spring:
  datasource:
    url: ${DATABASE_URL}  # From environment variable!
    username: ${DATABASE_USERNAME}
    password: ${DATABASE_PASSWORD}
  jpa:
    hibernate:
      ddl-auto: validate  # NEVER recreate production DB!
    show-sql: false  # Don't log SQL (performance)

Activate profile when running:
java -jar myapp.jar --spring.profiles.active=prod

Or set environment variable:
export SPRING_PROFILES_ACTIVE=prod
java -jar myapp.jar

contentSections.title: Environment Variables for Secrets
contentSections.content:
NEVER commit secrets to Git!

‚ùå BAD - Hardcoded in application.yml:
spring.datasource.password=mysecretpassword
jwt.secret=my-super-secret-key-12345

‚úì GOOD - Environment variables:
spring.datasource.password=${DATABASE_PASSWORD}
jwt.secret=${JWT_SECRET}

Set on server:
export DATABASE_PASSWORD='actual-secret-password'
export JWT_SECRET='actual-jwt-secret-key'
java -jar myapp.jar

Or pass directly:
java -jar myapp.jar \
  --spring.datasource.password=secret123 \
  --jwt.secret=my-jwt-key

Spring Boot automatically converts:
DATABASE_URL ‚Üí spring.datasource.url
DATABASE_USERNAME ‚Üí spring.datasource.username
DATABASE_PASSWORD ‚Üí spring.datasource.password

Why environment variables?
‚úì Different values per environment (dev, test, prod)
‚úì Secrets not in Git (security)
‚úì Easy to change without rebuilding
‚úì Cloud platforms (AWS, Azure, Heroku) support them

contentSections.title: Docker Deployment (Modern Standard)
contentSections.content:
Docker packages your app + Java + OS into one container

Benefits:
‚úì Runs the same everywhere (your laptop, AWS, Azure)
‚úì No 'it works on my machine' problems
‚úì Easy to scale (run 10 copies)
‚úì Isolated from other apps

Simple Dockerfile:

contentSections.title: Use official Java image
contentSections.content: FROM eclipse-temurin:17-jre

contentSections.title: Set working directory
contentSections.content: WORKDIR /app

contentSections.title: Copy JAR file
contentSections.content: COPY target/myapp.jar app.jar

contentSections.title: Expose port
contentSections.content: EXPOSE 8080

contentSections.title: Run application
contentSections.content:
ENTRYPOINT ["java", "-jar", "app.jar"]

Build Docker image:
docker build -t myapp:1.0 .

Run container:
docker run -p 8080:8080 \
  -e DATABASE_URL=jdbc:postgresql://db:5432/myapp \
  -e DATABASE_PASSWORD=secret \
  myapp:1.0

Access app: http://localhost:8080

contentSections.title: Multi-Stage Docker Build (Best Practice 2024-2025)
contentSections.content: Build and run in same Dockerfile - smaller final image:

contentSections.title: Stage 1: Build
contentSections.content:
FROM eclipse-temurin:17-jdk as builder
WORKDIR /app
COPY pom.xml .
COPY src ./src
RUN ./mvnw clean package -DskipTests

contentSections.title: Stage 2: Run
contentSections.content:
FROM eclipse-temurin:17-jre
WORKDIR /app
COPY --from=builder /app/target/myapp.jar app.jar
EXPOSE 8080
ENTRYPOINT ["java", "-jar", "app.jar"]

Why multi-stage?
‚úì Smaller image (no Maven, no source code)
‚úì Faster downloads
‚úì More secure (fewer tools = less attack surface)

Image sizes:
- Single stage with JDK: ~500 MB
- Multi-stage with JRE: ~250 MB

Layer optimization (Spring Boot 2.3+):
Separate layers for dependencies vs your code:

contentSections.title: Extract layers
contentSections.content:
FROM eclipse-temurin:17-jdk as builder
WORKDIR /app
COPY target/myapp.jar app.jar
RUN java -Djarmode=layertools -jar app.jar extract

contentSections.title: Run with layers
contentSections.content:
FROM eclipse-temurin:17-jre
WORKDIR /app
COPY --from=builder /app/dependencies/ ./
COPY --from=builder /app/spring-boot-loader/ ./
COPY --from=builder /app/snapshot-dependencies/ ./
COPY --from=builder /app/application/ ./
ENTRYPOINT ["java", "org.springframework.boot.loader.JarLauncher"]

Benefit: Dependencies cached, only your code layer changes!

contentSections.title: Production-Ready Features
‚ö†Ô∏è Production Security Checklist
contentSections.content:
Before deploying to production:

‚úì HTTPS only (no HTTP)
server.ssl.enabled=true

‚úì Hide actuator endpoints from public
management.endpoints.web.exposure.include=health

contentSections.title: Or require authentication
contentSections.content:
‚úì Disable debug mode
logging.level.root=INFO  # Not DEBUG

‚úì Don't show SQL queries
spring.jpa.show-sql=false

‚úì Validate database schema only
spring.jpa.hibernate.ddl-auto=validate  # NOT create-drop!

‚úì Use environment variables for secrets

contentSections.title: Never hardcode passwords
contentSections.content:
‚úì Enable CORS only for your frontend
@CrossOrigin(origins = "https://myapp.com")

contentSections.title: NOT @CrossOrigin("*")
contentSections.content: ‚úì Set reasonable rate limits

contentSections.title: Prevent abuse
contentSections.content:
‚úì Log to files, not just console
logging.file.name=/var/log/myapp.log

‚úì Set up monitoring and alerts

```java
STEP 1: Build the application
./mvnw clean package

STEP 2: Create Dockerfile
FROM eclipse-temurin:17-jre
WORKDIR /app
COPY target/myapp.jar app.jar
EXPOSE 8080
HEALTHCHECK --interval=30s --timeout=3s \
  CMD curl -f http://localhost:8080/actuator/health || exit 1
ENTRYPOINT ["java", "-jar", "app.jar"]

STEP 3: Create docker-compose.yml
version: '3.8'
services:
  db:
    image: postgres:15
    environment:
      POSTGRES_DB: myapp
      POSTGRES_USER: appuser
      POSTGRES_PASSWORD: ${DB_PASSWORD}
    volumes:
      - postgres-data:/var/lib/postgresql/data
    
  app:
    build: .
    ports:
      - "8080:8080"
    environment:

volumes:

STEP 4: Create .env file (DON'T commit this!)

STEP 5: Deploy

STEP 6: Check health
curl http://localhost:8080/actuator/health

STEP 7: View logs
docker-compose logs -f app

STEP 8: Update application
./mvnw clean package
docker-compose build app
docker-compose up -d app
```

contentSections.title: The Full-Stack Feature Journey
contentSections.content:
Let's build a complete feature: USER TASK MANAGEMENT

Feature: Users can create, view, update, and delete tasks

THE COMPLETE STACK:

1. DATABASE (PostgreSQL):
   - tasks table (id, title, description, completed, user_id)

2. BACKEND (Spring Boot):
   - Task entity (Java class mapped to database)
   - TaskRepository (database access)
   - TaskService (business logic)
   - TaskController (REST API endpoints)

3. API LAYER (REST):
   - GET /api/tasks - List all tasks
   - POST /api/tasks - Create task
   - PUT /api/tasks/{id} - Update task
   - DELETE /api/tasks/{id} - Delete task

4. FRONTEND (HTML + JavaScript):
   - Task list display
   - Create task form
   - Mark complete button
   - Delete button

We'll build this step-by-step, bottom-up!

contentSections.title: Building a Feature is Like Building a Highway System
contentSections.content:
DATABASE (The land/foundation):
Where everything is stored permanently
Like: The actual roads built into the ground

ENTITY (The blueprint):
Defines what a 'Task' looks like in Java
Like: Highway specifications (lanes, width, materials)

REPOSITORY (The construction crew):
Builds, reads, updates, destroys database records
Like: Workers who build and maintain the roads

SERVICE (Traffic management):
Business rules (e.g., can't delete someone else's task)
Like: Traffic laws and management systems

CONTROLLER (Toll booths/entrances):
Where requests come in and responses go out
Like: Highway entrances/exits with toll systems

FRONTEND (The cars and drivers):
What users actually see and interact with
Like: People driving cars on the highway

All parts must work together!

contentSections.title: Step 1: Database Schema
contentSections.content:
Create the tasks table:

CREATE TABLE tasks (
    id BIGSERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    title VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
    description TEXT,
    completed BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE,
    user_id BIGINT NOT NULL,
    created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    updated_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    FOREIGN KEY (user_id) REFERENCES users(id) ON DELETE CASCADE
);

Key decisions:
- BIGSERIAL: Auto-incrementing ID
- VARCHAR(255): Short text for title
- TEXT: Longer text for description
- BOOLEAN: True/false for completed status
- TIMESTAMP: When created/updated
- FOREIGN KEY: Links to users table
- ON DELETE CASCADE: Delete tasks when user deleted

Spring Boot can create this automatically:

application.yml:
spring:
  jpa:
    hibernate:
      ddl-auto: update  # Creates/updates tables automatically

contentSections.title: üíª Step 7: Create the Frontend (JavaScript)
‚ö†Ô∏è Common Full-Stack Mistakes
contentSections.content:
‚ùå MISTAKE 1: Not handling errors
Frontend sends request, backend fails, UI shows nothing
FIX: try-catch everywhere, display errors to user

‚ùå MISTAKE 2: No loading states
User clicks button, waits... did it work?
FIX: Show 'Loading...' or disable buttons during requests

‚ùå MISTAKE 3: Not escaping user input
User enters: <script>alert('hacked')</script>
FIX: Use escapeHtml() or textContent instead of innerHTML

‚ùå MISTAKE 4: Missing CORS configuration
Frontend: http://localhost:3000
Backend: http://localhost:8080
Browser blocks request!
FIX: @CrossOrigin on controller

‚ùå MISTAKE 5: Not validating on backend
Trust frontend validation? Attacker bypasses it!
FIX: ALWAYS validate on backend with @Valid

‚ùå MISTAKE 6: Exposing IDs without authorization
User can delete task ID 123, not theirs!
FIX: Check task.userId === currentUserId

‚ùå MISTAKE 7: N+1 query problem
Loading 100 tasks ‚Üí 101 database queries!
FIX: Use @EntityGraph or JOIN FETCH

contentSections.title: Why Planning Matters
contentSections.content:
You've learned Java, Spring Boot, databases, and frontend.

‚úì WITH PLANNING:

contentSections.title: Planning a Project is Like Planning a Road Trip

DESTINATION (Project vision):

Pick something you're excited about!

contentSections.title: Step 2: Define Your MVP (Minimum Viable Product)
contentSections.content:
MVP = Simplest version that actually works

Example: Task Manager MVP

‚úì IN MVP (Core features only):
- User registration and login
- Create a task (title + description)
- View list of my tasks
- Mark task as complete
- Delete a task

‚ùå NOT IN MVP (Nice-to-have features):

WHY START WITH MVP?

contentSections.title: Step 3: Write User Stories
contentSections.content:
User stories describe features from user's perspective.

FORMAT:
As a [user type], I want [goal] so that [reason].

Example User Stories for Task Manager:

STORY 1: User Registration
As a new user,
I want to create an account with email and password,
So that I can save my tasks and access them later.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Email must be valid format
- Password must be at least 8 characters
- Cannot register with existing email
- Shows success message after registration

STORY 2: User Login
As a registered user,
I want to log in with my email and password,
So that I can access my tasks.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Redirect to task list after successful login
- Show error if credentials are wrong
- Stay logged in until I log out

STORY 3: Create Task
As a logged-in user,
I want to create a new task with a title and description,
So that I can remember what I need to do.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Title is required (cannot be empty)
- Description is optional
- New task appears in my task list immediately
- Show success message

STORY 4: View Task List
As a logged-in user,
I want to see all my tasks in a list,
So that I can see what I need to do.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Show only MY tasks (not other users' tasks)
- Display title, description, and completion status
- Show message if I have no tasks

STORY 5: Mark Task Complete
As a logged-in user,
I want to mark a task as complete,
So that I can track my progress.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Completed tasks show a checkmark
- Can toggle between complete and incomplete
- Changes saved to database immediately

STORY 6: Delete Task
As a logged-in user,
I want to delete a task I no longer need,
So that my task list stays clean.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Confirm before deleting ("Are you sure?")
- Task removed from database immediately
- Cannot delete other users' tasks

email         VARCHAR(255) UNIQUE NOT NULL
password      VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL  (hashed!)
name          VARCHAR(100)

3. What should be required vs optional?

contentSections.title: The Data Layer Foundation
contentSections.content:
You've set up your project. Now let's build the data layer!

THE DATA LAYER (Bottom of the stack):

1. ENTITIES (Java classes ‚Üí Database tables)
   @Entity, @Table, @Id, @Column
   Example: User class ‚Üí users table

2. REPOSITORIES (Database access layer)
   JpaRepository interface
   Spring generates SQL automatically!

WHY START HERE?
‚úì Foundation for everything else
‚úì Can test immediately (no UI needed)
‚úì Database schema auto-created by Hibernate
‚úì Easy to debug when isolated

BUILD ORDER:
1. Create User entity
2. Create UserRepository
3. Test with @SpringBootTest
4. Create Task entity
5. Create TaskRepository
6. Test relationships

Let's build from the ground up!

contentSections.title: Entities and Repositories are Like Blueprint and Builder
contentSections.content:
ENTITY (The blueprint):
Detailed architectural plan for a house
Like: User class defines what a user looks like
Specifies: id, email, password, name, created date

@Entity annotation = "This is a blueprint for a database table"
@Id annotation = "This is the house number (unique identifier)"
@Column = "This is a room in the house"

REPOSITORY (The builder/contractor):
The construction crew that builds houses from blueprints
Like: UserRepository saves/finds users in database

save() = Build a new house
findById() = Find house by address
findAll() = List all houses in neighborhood
delete() = Demolish a house

Spring Data JPA = The crew manager
You just say "build me a house"
Spring figures out HOW to do it (generates SQL)

contentSections.title: Step 1: Create the User Entity
Understanding Entity Annotations
contentSections.content:
KEY ANNOTATIONS EXPLAINED:

@Entity
- Marks class as JPA entity
- Hibernate will create database table for this class

@Table(name = "users")
- Specifies table name in database
- Without this, table name = class name ("User")
- Best practice: explicit table names

@Id
- Marks the primary key field
- Every entity MUST have @Id

@GeneratedValue(strategy = GenerationType.IDENTITY)
- Database auto-generates ID (1, 2, 3, ...)
- IDENTITY = uses database auto-increment
- Other options: SEQUENCE, AUTO, UUID

@Column(nullable = false, unique = true, length = 255)
- nullable = false ‚Üí SQL: NOT NULL
- unique = true ‚Üí SQL: UNIQUE constraint
- length = 255 ‚Üí SQL: VARCHAR(255)
- name = "created_at" ‚Üí column name different from field name

@OneToMany(mappedBy = "user", cascade = CascadeType.ALL)
- One user has many tasks (1:N relationship)
- mappedBy = "user" ‚Üí Tasks have a 'user' field
- cascade = ALL ‚Üí Save/delete user cascades to tasks
- orphanRemoval = true ‚Üí Delete task if removed from list

@PrePersist
- Lifecycle callback: runs before INSERT
- Automatically sets createdAt timestamp
- Other callbacks: @PreUpdate, @PostLoad, etc.

contentSections.title: Step 2: Create the Task Entity
Understanding Relationships
contentSections.content:
@ManyToOne (Task side - many tasks to one user):
@ManyToOne(fetch = FetchType.LAZY)
@JoinColumn(name = "user_id", nullable = false)
private User user;

- Many tasks belong to one user
- FetchType.LAZY = Don't load user until accessed
- JoinColumn = Creates 'user_id' foreign key column
- nullable = false = Every task MUST have a user

@OneToMany (User side - one user to many tasks):
@OneToMany(mappedBy = "user", cascade = CascadeType.ALL)
private List<Task> tasks = new ArrayList<>();

- One user has many tasks
- mappedBy = "user" = Task entity owns the relationship
- cascade = ALL = Operations cascade (save, delete, etc.)
- orphanRemoval = true = Delete orphaned tasks

DATABASE RESULT:
users table:
  id | email           | password | name
  1  | alice@email.com | hashed   | Alice

tasks table:
  id | title      | description | completed | user_id
  1  | Buy milk   | From store  | false     | 1
  2  | Walk dog   | 30 minutes  | true      | 1

LAZY vs EAGER Fetching:
LAZY (recommended):
- Loads relationship only when accessed
- Better performance
- Avoids N+1 query problem

EAGER (use sparingly):
- Loads relationship immediately
- Can cause performance issues
- Use only for small, always-needed data

contentSections.title: Step 3: Create UserRepository
Step 4: Create TaskRepository
üíª Testing Your Repositories
‚ö†Ô∏è Common Entity and Repository Mistakes
contentSections.content:
‚ùå MISTAKE 1: No default constructor
public class User {
    // Only parameterized constructor
    public User(String email) { ... }
}
FIX: JPA requires no-arg constructor:
public User() {}

‚ùå MISTAKE 2: Forgot @Id annotation
JPA doesn't know which field is the primary key
FIX: Always mark primary key with @Id

‚ùå MISTAKE 3: Storing plain text passwords
private String password = "password123";  // NEVER!
FIX: Hash passwords before storing (BCrypt)

‚ùå MISTAKE 4: EAGER fetching relationships
@OneToMany(fetch = FetchType.EAGER)
Causes N+1 query problem, poor performance
FIX: Use LAZY (default for @OneToMany)

‚ùå MISTAKE 5: Exposing entities to controllers
return userRepository.findAll();  // Returns password field!
FIX: Use DTOs (Data Transfer Objects)

‚ùå MISTAKE 6: Not handling Optional
User user = userRepository.findById(id);  // Compile error!
FIX: Optional<User> user = userRepository.findById(id);
      user.orElseThrow(() -> new NotFoundException(...));

‚ùå MISTAKE 7: Circular references in JSON
User has tasks, Task has user ‚Üí infinite loop!
FIX: Use @JsonIgnore or DTOs

contentSections.title: Best Practices Summary
contentSections.content:
ENTITIES:
‚úì Always provide no-arg constructor
‚úì Use @Table with explicit table name
‚úì Use @Column for nullable, unique, length constraints
‚úì Use LAZY fetching for relationships
‚úì Use @PrePersist/@PreUpdate for timestamps
‚úì Don't expose entities directly to API

REPOSITORIES:
‚úì Extend JpaRepository<Entity, ID>
‚úì Use query method naming conventions
‚úì Use @Query for complex queries
‚úì Return Optional<T> for single results
‚úì Use @DataJpaTest for testing
‚úì Keep repositories thin (logic in service layer)

DATABASE:
‚úì Use spring.jpa.hibernate.ddl-auto=update in dev
‚úì Use validate in production
‚úì Enable show-sql in development
‚úì Use indexes for frequently queried columns
‚úì Test with real database (PostgreSQL), not just H2

contentSections.content:
Right now, ANYONE can access your API!

CURRENT PROBLEM:

‚úì Protection against common attacks
‚úì JWT token support (stateless auth)

TWO APPROACHES:
1. SESSION-BASED (Simpler, for beginners)

   - Session stored on server
   - Good for traditional web apps

2. TOKEN-BASED (JWT)

   - Client sends token with each request
   - Stateless, good for APIs

LEARNING PATH:
This lesson: HTTP Basic Auth (simple, for testing)
Later lessons: JWT tokens (production-ready)

NOTE: Basic Auth is NOT recommended for production.
We use it here to understand Spring Security fundamentals.
You'll learn JWT (the production standard) in upcoming lessons!

contentSections.content:
‚ùå MISTAKE 1: Storing plain passwords
user.setPassword("password123");  // NEVER!

‚ùå MISTAKE 3: Not disabling CSRF for APIs

FIX: .csrf().disable() in SecurityFilterChain

‚ùå MISTAKE 4: Returning password in API responses

‚ùå MISTAKE 7: Hard-coding user IDs

      - postgres-data:/var/lib/postgresql/data
    ports:
      - "5432:5432"
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD-SHELL", "pg_isready -U taskuser"]
      interval: 10s
      timeout: 5s
      retries: 5
    networks:
      - taskmanager-network

  # Spring Boot Application
  app:
    build:
      context: .
      dockerfile: Dockerfile
    container_name: taskmanager-app
    environment:
      SPRING_PROFILES_ACTIVE: prod
      SPRING_DATASOURCE_URL: jdbc:postgresql://db:5432/taskmanager
      SPRING_DATASOURCE_USERNAME: ${DB_USER:-taskuser}
      SPRING_DATASOURCE_PASSWORD: ${DB_PASSWORD:?Database password required}
      SPRING_JPA_HIBERNATE_DDL_AUTO: validate
      SERVER_PORT: 8080
    ports:
      - "8080:8080"
    depends_on:
      db:
        condition: service_healthy
    restart: unless-stopped
    networks:
      - taskmanager-network

volumes:
  postgres-data:

networks:
  taskmanager-network:
    driver: bridge

KEY FEATURES:
‚úì Environment variables (secure secrets)
‚úì Health checks (wait for database)
‚úì Named volumes (persistent data)
‚úì Custom network (container communication)
‚úì Restart policy (automatic recovery)

contentSections.title: ‚ö†Ô∏è Common Deployment Mistakes
contentSections.content:
‚ùå MISTAKE 1: Using development profile in production
ddl-auto: create-drop (deletes all data on restart!)
FIX: SPRING_PROFILES_ACTIVE=prod, ddl-auto: validate

‚ùå MISTAKE 2: Hardcoding database URL
url: jdbc:postgresql://localhost:5432/db
FIX: Use environment variables

‚ùå MISTAKE 3: No health checks
Container appears running but app is crashed
FIX: Add HEALTHCHECK in Dockerfile

‚ùå MISTAKE 4: Root user in container
Security vulnerability
FIX: Create non-root user in Dockerfile

‚ùå MISTAKE 5: Exposing sensitive endpoints
/actuator/env shows all environment variables!
FIX: Restrict actuator endpoints in production

‚ùå MISTAKE 6: No database backups
Data loss if server fails
FIX: Configure automated backups

‚ùå MISTAKE 7: Ignoring logs
App fails, no idea why
FIX: Set up log monitoring (Papertrail, Loggly)

‚ùå MISTAKE 8: No rollback plan
Deployment breaks everything
FIX: Keep previous version, test before full rollout
